results.notes:
Pleurotus species. I have encountered this one numerous times in spring and fall all around my area.

I do not think this is Pleurocybella porrigens.

- Flesh is fairly thick but you can tell the light comes through. Bends then breaks. When old is more crumbly/gritty.
- Often home to many little black beetles when i find it.
- Odor is faintly anise. Some specimens have stronger smell than others.
- Often the cap flesh has a lot of embedded material. Cannot tell if this is particles from the tree than get grown over or not. Seems to be very common for this species when i find it. Often more so towards the attachment point. Running your fingers over it you can feel the grittyness.
- Found on downed tree but have also found on live ones as well. Often in large clusters. Specimens in the 20cm range were not uncommon.
- Whitish spore print.
results.location_name: Greenwood Cemetery, Grand Rapids, Michigan, USA

results.notes:
Grey morels.

In recent years I had not encountered them in this location before.

Growing among the Podophyllum / mayapple plants (they didn’t make it up!).

Area has been a good producer of Morchella semilibera / half free morels every year i have checked.

Ground was only slightly spongy. Starting to notice a pattern on how much moisture morels seem to like.

I will have to note the tree species around there on my next visit.

results.notes: In mixed woods. Oak, Ash, Hickory, White Pine. I don’t believe latex or waxy gills were present, but there are many Russulas found throughout the year in this area. Caps were 4-5 cm dia. Stipe 10-12 mm at the apex tapering downwards, brittle, and stuffed.Pileal trama soft, white, 7mm thick at apex and 2mm thick near the margin. Odor pleasant, taste slightly bitter.

results.notes:
Coprinellus micaceus / Coprinus micaceus in various stages of development.

I personally seem to find a lot of it in the spring, often growing profusely in clusters.

Note the Polyporus squamosus on the other trees – i often see the two growing in the same area. However i don’t recall how often they share a tree.

They seem to enjoy the dying elms with peeling bark, with the ground being pretty damp and squishy. I have a few locations i have noticed this.

results.notes:
I regret picking these… My hands were stained light olive brown, and once it dried had the feel as if superglue had dried to my hands. Could not wash off easily and was difficult to pick off.

They are edible. I cooked up a few but not sure how i felt about it. They were somewhere between mushy and cooked-puffball texture.

- Fruited flushes two or three times over the course of a month or two from what i noticed.
- Created enormous fairy rings around many of the pines
- Olive spore print

Warning: that day, i developed some kind of rash that was similar to poison ivy, but not. I believe it started before i even touched these, but cannot be certain. It was incredibly itchy. I had the same thing the previous year which i contracted up north. I believe i also encountered a sullius species there as well. I have read some bits of data online about allergic reactions from sullius slime. I cannot say if this is really what happened, but it is suspicious.

A coworker also had contracted the same thing as i a week later. However he had not touched any mushrooms. He was out in the woods however.

results.notes: This robust and attractive specimen, featuring a well-preserved and prominent double annulus and growing late in the season, was collected in the North Gate area of FPP. This mushroom was displayed at NJMA’s annual Fungus Fest public event at Frelinghuysen Arboretum on Nov. 1st, but probably not saved.

results.notes:
Found growing in the soil in clusters.

Cap: 3-15 cm, convex to broadly convex or flat in age; the margin often arched in maturity; color typically honey yellow; smooth, or with a few tiny, dark scales concentrated near the center and vaguely radially arranged.

Gills: Attached or beginning to run down the stem; nearly distant; whitish, sometimes bruising or discoloring darker.

Stem: 5-20 cm long; .5-3.5 cm thick; tapering to base due to clustered growth pattern; tough and fibrous; smooth and pale near apex, darker and nearly hairy below; with a persistent ring at maturity and a white partial veil covering the gills when young.

Flesh: Whitish to watery tan.

Odor and Taste: Taste mild to bitter; odor sweet.

Spore Print: White.

Microscopic Features: Spores 7-9 × 6-7 µ; smooth; more or less elliptical; inamyloid; with a prominent apiculus. Basidia lacking basal clamps.

results.notes:
Growing on the ground in conifer duff.

Cap: 7-17 mm across; convex to broadly convex or flat, often with a shallow central depression; bald; tacky to dry; sometimes becoming widely lined on the margin; orange-brown to reddish brown or yellow-brown, often with a darker center.

Gills: Broadly attached to the stem or just beginning to run down it; close or nearly distant; with many cross-veins; pale yellow; short-gills frequent.

Stem: 1-3 cm long; 1-2 mm thick; more or less equal above a slightly swollen base; yellowish above, reddish brown to dark brown below; finely hairy or nearly bald above; base covered with orangish to rusty hairs.

Flesh: Insubstantial.

Odor and Taste: Not distinctive.

Chemical Reactions: KOH bright red on cap surface.

Spore Print: White.

Microscopic Features: Spores 5-8 × 3-4 µ; elliptical; smooth; faintly to moderately amyloid.

results.notes:

results.notes:
Growing from the soil in forest debris.

Cap: Up to 2.5 cm across; conical to broadly conical, sometimes becoming bell-shaped; dry; when young with a hoary sheen, but often more or less bald at maturity; pale grayish brown, fading to grayish with a slightly darker center; the margin lined nearly to the center.

Gills: Attached to the stem by a tooth; close or nearly distant; whitish or pale grayish.

Stem: 5-12 cm long; 1-3 mm thick; fragile in age; equal; hollow; finely hoary at first, but soon bald; pale above and brownish to grayish below, but sometimes with faint bluish or lilac shades; basal mycelium hairy and white.

Odor and Taste: Odor usually of iodine but sometimes only weakly so, or not distinctive; taste not distinctive.

Spore Print: White.

Microscopic Features: Spores 7-11 × 5-7 µ; weakly to moderately amyloid; elliptical; smooth.

Possibly well desiccated.

results.notes:

Cap: 5-75 cm (!) across; more or less fan-shaped, semicircular, or irregular; with a dull, unvarnished outer crust; often furrowed in “zones”; brownish to grayish brown.

Pore Surface: White, becoming dirty yellowish or dingy brownish to olive in age; bruising brown; with 4-6 tiny (nearly invisible to the naked eye) circular pores per mm; tubes in layers (a new layer is added each year), separated by brown tissue, with each layer 4-12 mm deep.

Stem: Usually absent; if present, lateral and stubby.

Chemical Reactions: Flesh and tubes black with KOH.

Spore Print: Brown or reddish brown.

Microscopic Features: Spores 8-12 × 6.5-8 µ; more or less elliptical, with a truncated end.

results.notes:
Found in pine needles.

Cap: 1-3 cm broad, convex, becoming nearly plane in age, the disc sometimes slightly depressed with an uplifted margin; surface translucent-striate when moist, faintly radially furrowed, otherwise smooth, pale grey to buff-grey, fading to ashy-white; flesh extremely thin, colored like the cap, unchanging; odor, mild.

Gills: subdecurrent becoming decurrent and distant at maturity, moderately broad, intervenose, concolorous with the cap, unchanging.

Stipe: 1.5-4 cm tall, 2-5 mm thick, fragile, hollow, equal to tapering to a slightly narrowed base; surface smooth, moist, white at the apex, pale-grey to dingy light-brown at the base; veil absent.

Spores: 9-10 × 3.5-4.5 µm, elliptical to tear-drop shaped, smooth, inamyloid; spore print white.

results.notes:
Found growing in clusters near conifers.

Cap: 3-15 cm wide; convex, becoming planoconvex; bald; very slimy; streaked; pale pinkish to brownish when young, becoming dark reddish brown to dark brown, or sometimes fading to tan; spotting and discoloring blackish to black in places or overall with age.

Gills: Running down the stem; close; pale buff at first, becoming smoky gray; short-gills frequent.

Stem: 5-10 cm long; 1-3 cm wide; tapering to base; often rooting; with a fibrillose partial veil that is typically poorly developed and hard to distinguish underneath the “slime veil” (a thick layer of clear slime sheathing the young stem and covering the gills); at maturity slimy over the lower portion; sometimes adorned with a ring or ring zone that becomes blackened by spores; whitish above, dull to bright yellow below; discoloring and bruising black.

Odor and Taste: Not distinctive.

Spore Print: Purplish gray to black.

Microscopic Features: Spores 10.5-14 × 4-6 µ; smooth; narrowly ellipsoid.

results.notes:
On igneus rock, a mixture of serpentinite and other stuff. Full sun exposure in semi-arid grassland habitat.

Thallus chocolate to dark brown, areolate to squamulose, plane to rounded convex, shiny, K-, C-. Squamules elevated above substrate on a broad attachment, not sure if it counts as a stipe or not. Apothecia immersed, deep red-brown to blackish, concave, I think without a parathecial crown (see photo). Medulla white, C- (observed at 400x). Algal layer seems even, without interrupting hyphal bundles. Asci with many spores, spores simple, hyaline, ellipsoid. Two spores measured 3.75/4.5 × 1.9/2.8µm. Diameter of paraphyses base not measured, but in relation to nearby spores they appear to be less than 2.3µm wide (see photo).

The lichenicolous fungi Endococcus parasitising this specimen is represented in a separate observation.

results.notes:
Growing in the debris accumulated on one large log and two rotten smaller logs in the same place.

Basidia 4-spored, ~22+6 x 8. Spores 9-10 × 4-5. Cheilocystidia forming a continuous band, 25-34 × 14-25, sessile or stipitate. Pileipellis a dense corraloid mass. Hyphae of the cortical layer of the stipe diverticulate; caulocystidia ~20 × 10.

The microscopy is a good match for M. filopes, except for cheilocystidia that are up to 50% out of range. The size is not typical, though minitature forms of filopes have been mentioned. More problematically, there was no iodine odor even after the mushrooms spent 12 hours in the fridge.

Habitat is old growth oak forest dominated by Quercus agrifolia, but also with interesting associates including madrone (Arbutus menziesii), lots of California bay (Umbellularia californica) and much less common this far south, tan oak (Lithocarpus densiflorus). Thallus white, somewhat thick, C-, K+Y. Apothecia lecanorine, crowded, yellowish white in maturity, densely mealy pruinose, disk C+Y, K-, but margin C-. Medulla appears C-; algal layer continuous in apothecial cross-section, somewhat discontinuous in mature material. Disks and thallus UV-.

results.notes:
Found growing single in soil/leaf litter beneath a live oak, also in the immediate vicinity of a manzanita bush.

Cap: 12.5 cm x 9 cm diameter (widest points)
Stipe: 9 cm long
Stipe diameter: 2.5 cm at base, 8 cm at widest point (bulbous), 5 cm near cap

Cap a wine-red color predominantly, transitioning to more orangish tones toward margin. Irregular, undulating in shape with a smooth dry, surface (slightly viscous when found).

Context yellow, tubes yellow, stipe yellow. In cross-section, slight reddish tinges in stipe toward base. Context blues gradually when cut; tubes blue when cut.

Tube openings relatively obvious (on large side), possibly angular, random pattern. Sometimes tinged brown.

Spores were olive-brown and elongated ellipsoid in shape, the latter consistent with “fusoid” description for proposed ID.

2% iron sulfate solution applied to cap produced a color change to a darker but nondescript color; not inconsistent with expected purple but more blackish.

2% iron sulfate solution applied to context produced grayish color, consistent with proposed ID.

Specimen weighed 9.3 oz.

results.notes:
A small robust Cortinarius with strikingly red lamellae. The pigment content is so high that a single fleck of gills stains the water droplet used to soak it in bright scarlet. My initial guess was C. phoeniceus (I used the Cortinarius in Sweden key), but the spores are off: roughly 4 × 8 µm, nearly smooth (vs. 6-7 × 3.5-4.5, elliptic/subamygdaloid and weakly/moderately verrucose).

Found growing in xeric Pinus sylvestris forest among mosses and Cladonia lichens.

results.notes:
Two similar specimens growing nearby each other in soil with oak leaf and pine needle cover. Found several feet from a live oak, in a grove of live oaks and adjacent to some gray pines.

Featured specimen had a dark gold cap, fading to light gold along its clearly striated top margin. Cap 11 cm in diameter, basically convex but mildly umbonate in shape with a distinct white 4-cm patch of tissue in center (partial veil).

Gills white, appear adnexed.

Stipe 18 cm long, cream-colored, cylindrical, 3 cm in diameter, constant width until coming to sharp point at tip.

Last 5-6 cm of stipe covered with a white volva.

Stately specimen!

Habitat: grassland; semiruderal, flat terrain near a village house; calcareous ground, shallow soil layer; nitrogen rich place (my dog’s favorite place to pee); open, fairly sunny place; mowed several times per year; exposed to direct rain; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7 – 9 deg C, elevation 600 m (1.970 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: soil.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, between villages Soča and Trenta, right bank of river Soča, Na Melu place, next to the cottage Trenta 2b, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments:
Bolbitius titubans is generally a common mushroom but apparently not in the Upper Soča River region. The place of this observation is almost in front of my house, where I live. I know this piece of grassland for decades. Yet, I have seen this mushrooms only once – in 2013. There were several dozens of them appearing again and again starting at the beginning of October until the end of November. Pilei are ephemeral and of similar habitus as in genus Coprinus but vividly lemon to yolk yellow, beautiful particularly when they are young. It is impossible to overlook them in low grass. They are viscid and very delicate. Growing solitary and in groups of a few fruit bodies; flesh very brittle; SP brown with reddish tint.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8

results.notes:
Found in a pasture, growing through straw. The closest tree was a blue Oak about 50+ feet away.

Cap: pale brownish gray, darker at center, very viscid (gathered when wet outside but retained this quality later). Bell shaped when young, umbonate when mature. No striations on cap, no odor, no brushing. Cap 9-14 cm in diameter.

Stipe: separates cleanly from cap, inside of stipe viscid too when cut lengthwise, white, 16 cm long x 2.5 cm diameter at mid stipe (largest specimen). Bulb/sac 5cm wide and 5cm high. Sac is white. Stipe mostly equal in length with very slight flare at top near cap. No annulus, stipe solid.

Spores: chocolate-cinnamon brown

“Epic” specimens!

Same exact location (to the nearest square foot) as obs 225211 .

As noted in BRB, a tasty edible mushroom.

Left the two buttons to mature, and hope to revisit site on Thursday/Friday.

Collected the larger of the two buttons Friday 12-18. Almost mature. Photos added. Photo taken after mushroom was sectioned on 12-19. Note how the glands on the stipe have developed/darkened.

Photos labeled “12-23 A” and “12-23 B” taken 12-23. Photo A shows one of the two mushrooms seen in the thumbnail photo. This mushroom has survived a spell of cold weather, including one 24 hour period when the temperature did not exceed 32F. Development has been very slow, despite the currently wet and warm weather.

results.notes: At first I thought this was Amanita phalloides, possibly var. Alba, but the absence of a ring doesn’t fit well. So I’m proposing Amanita vaginata var. alba based on the key found on http://www.mushroomexpert.com/amanita.html. The specimen was perfect and was growing along a path on the De Anza College Campus in some wood chips near some ornamental bushes, not directly under any trees, although there were cypress trees not far away.
